When they are crossing from your right only.

questions.qn: You must give way to pedestrians on a marked pedestrian crossing -

options: Slow down and be ready to make a safe stop.
Come to a complete stop before the crossing
Go faster, in case a pedestrian steps onto the crossing.
questions.qn: When approaching a marked pedestrian crossing and no pedestrians are in sight, you should -

options: Drive around them so you don't hold up traffic.
Sound your horn to hurry them up.
Wait extra time to allow them to cross safely.
questions.qn: If elderly people or children are on a pedestrian crossing you will probably need to –

options: A
B
C
questions.qn: Which sign painted on the road tells you there is a pedestrian crossing ahead?

options: May overtake the vehicle provided no cars are coming the other way.
May overtake the vehicle if there are no pedestrians on the crossing.
Must not overtake the stopped vehicle.
questions.qn: A vehicle ahead of you has stopped at a pedestrian crossing. You -

options: Are out of sight
Reach the right-hand side of the crossing.
Are off the crossing and the hand held sign is taken away.
questions.qn: If you see a School Crossing Supervisor holding a sign like this, you must wait until the children -

options: May not travel on heavy traffic roads.
Must obey the road rules.
Must ride against the flow of traffic so they can be seen.
questions.qn: Which one of the following statements is correct? Bicycle riders -

options: Slow down, and be ready to make a safe stop.
Sound your horn to warn them of your presence.
Continue at the same speed and drive around them.
questions.qn: When driving near children playing or walking near the edge of the road, you should

options: Less dangerous than sober pedestrians because they are more careful after drinking.
Unlikely to walk near the road and do not require your attention.
One of the most common groups involved in road accidents.
questions.qn: Pedestrians who are affected by alcohol, are -

options: Move into the left lane.
Slow down, watch for pedestrians and be ready to make a safe stop.
Keep your eyes on the speedo.
questions.qn: When driving near pedestrian crossings, intersections, or school crossings, you should always -

options: Slow down and watch for an indication that they will enter the road.
Put your headlights on high beam so they can see you better.
Increase your speed to avoid the chance of hitting them.
questions.qn: When driving in an area where there are many pedestrians (e.g. a bus stop) it is important to -

options: Watch for pedestrians, animals and car doors opening.
Drive in the right-hand lane, if there is one.
Stay as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.qn: When driving past parked vehicles, which of the following is it most important to do –

options: Stop and help aged pedestrians across the road.
Drive in the middle of the road to avoid splashing pedestrians on the footpath.
Watch out for pedestrians, who may hurry and take risks.
questions.qn: When driving in wet weather, you should -

options: The green light is due. Do not proceed until the green light appears.
You may carefully drive through the crossing, if there is no risk of colliding with pedestrians.
The traffic lights are out of order and pedestrians must not use the crossing.
questions.qn: At a pedestrian crossing with traffic lights, when the amber light starts 'flashing' after the red stop signal, it means -

options: You must give way to pedestrians if there is any danger of hitting them.
Pedestrians have no special rights on the roads.
You must give way to pedestrians only at marked crossings.
